newsitem.title: UK: Sterling firmer against generally softer mark.
newsitem.headline: Sterling firmer against generally softer mark.

text.p: Sterling was higher against the mark, buoyed by the German unit's weakness in the wake of the European Union's agreement on a stability pact aimed at ensuring the planned start of monetary union in 1999. "The main story is the mark and its weakness on the European crosses after the stability pact agreement gave a helping hand to sterling," said Adam Cole, economist at HSBC James Capel.
The agreement on a stability pact, hammered out by EU leaders on Monday at their summit in Amsterdam - which concludes today - is aimed at budget discipline after EMU begins.
Analysts said the agreement, which included a resolution on jobs and growth creation in Europe, increased the risk of a soft single currency.
Sterling was little moved by public sector borrowing data showing the PSBR was above forecasts in May. The PSBR hit 3.96 billion pounds, compared with market forecasts for a 2.9 billion shortfall.
At 1045 GMT the pound was at 2.8390/00, up from 2.8295/05 in late European trading on Monday.
But the pound's tone was consolidative after it revisited 57-month peaks above 2.84 marks on Monday. Traders said no great shakes were expected ahead of the UK budget on July 2.
"It looks a little tired, frankly, up here," said Simon Cook, head of trading at Co-operative Bank in London, adding that he expected an attack on trendline support around 2.8180/8200 marks.
The pound's upside against the dollar was limited by the generally firmer dollar. Cable was at $1.6355/65 against $1.6349/54 in late Europe on Monday.
